newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: Lithuania brewer picks Hartwall unit as partner.
newsitem.headline: Lithuania brewer picks Hartwall unit as partner.

text.p: Lithuania's Utenos Beverages said on Monday that its shareholder meeting voted to form a closed joint stock company with Baltic Beverage Holdings, owned by Finnish Hartwall and Norway's Orkla.
Danish brewer Carlsberg had also offered to invest into the Lithuanian brewer, one of the leading beer makers in the Baltic state.

"Some 68.65 percent of those participating in the general shareholders' meeting voted for a decision to found a closed joint stock company with BBH," Utenos director general Stasys Krasauskas told Reuters.
He also said that 82.5 percent of those shareholders who had a voting right attended the meeting. The shareholders of Utena had to choose between Carlsberg and BBH.
"The state representative, who represented a 21.5 percent stake in the firm abstained, in the vote," Krasauskas said.
He said that Utenos would pass all its assets, trade marks and business to the new company, which it would split 50/50 with Baltic Beverage.
Each stake would have a face value of 50 million litas.
BBH will invest into the firm 50 million litas, he added.
The Finnish-Norwegian joint venture also said it would pay shareholders 300 litas per share with a face value of 100 litas after they have been quoted on the Vilnius bourse.
BBH is already one of the largest beer makers in the Baltics, owning the leading beer makers in each of the three Baltic states.
